rss.title: True Cross
rss.subtitle: Does it exist? Where is it?

subtitle_detail.value: Does it exist? Where is it?

transcription.full_transcript: Welcome to Catholic Stuff You Should Know, a J-10 initiative. Hey and welcome. This is Catholic Stuff You Should Know. Father John and my good friend Joe Doman here. Hi. With you. Welcome back. So what are we talking about today? Last time we recorded together, we didn't even get to the topics. We just talked about Mumford for 20 minutes. Should we reveal this was the topic that was going to be on the last one? This was. This is the hidden secret topic. And we're still in the cave in kind of our new location. So we rotate where we record these based on our kind of crazy schedules. Mm hmm. but it works out where we can do these here down in Denver. Yes. But Joe's room is a very strange room. He's got his closet behind him, but it's not even a closet. It's just this kind of rack. It's a clothes rack. Stuff on it. Stuff on it. We have a septic pipe running across the ceiling. Great work. It's awesome. Great photo of Newman, Tolkien, and Chesterton on the wall, which I think I... put there. I know. I just, I have nothing to replace it with. So, it's a great room. Some, maybe we'll put a picture of it on the website, but probably not. We'll probably forget to do that. Yeah, we probably, I don't even want to do that really, so. Yeah, well, I got a shout out before we start. Yeah, go ahead. Laura Gifford. Laura. Laura brought Maker's Mark to my rectory. She's friends with Father Peter. She's a spiritual director of Father Brian, that British priest. That's right. She's been passing on the podcast to other people, including Matt McCartney, who's a friend and parishioner of mine. Is he the coach of the Packers? He's not. Okay. That's a different guy. This guy has four little girls who are very cute and very well-behaved in the front row at my parish. Nice. to feed your addictions. That's great. I'm glad you have Maker's Mark. Oh, I was like, okay, thank you. Maker's Mark. Yeah, right? Yeah, so thank you, Laura, for the Makers. It's a long time coming, but we're grateful for it. Hey, that's awesome. But not this morning. This morning, it's all suffering and pain. It's all suffering and coffee without cream. Coffee without cream, as we talk about. The true cross. The true cross. Why we're here. The cross. That's right. I wanted to do this topic because, well, the Feast of the True Cross, Exaltation of the True Cross, was not too long ago. a couple weeks ago, at least when I initially had this idea. But cool little story. My parish, where I'm assigned in the seminary, McElhart and Mary in North Glen with Fr. Brian Larkin, we're at the same parish together. It's great. But I don't know if you knew this, John, Fr. John, but we have a relic of the true cross that was recently given to the church. Really? Yeah. There was a couple, an old couple, who I think were fallen away Catholics. This is at least how it was related to me by the pastor. They were falling away Catholics, and they were moving out of their house they'd been living in for years. And they were cleaning out their attic or whatever, and they found this relic. And they didn't know what it was. Well, I think they knew what it was, but they didn't really care much. Because when they were a young, young couple, when they first got married, some priest gave it to them as a gift. and they had kind of fallen away from the faith, and they were married for like 60 years or whatever, so this kind of just sat in their attic for years, and now they're like, hey, we don't have any use for this, but there's a Catholic church nearby. Maybe they could do something with it. So it ends up being a relic of the true cross from the 1600s. The reliquary is absolutely gorgeous. Oh, it's a full reliquary and everything. The reliquary is beautiful. I've never seen a reliquary like it. It's absolutely beautiful. Do you want to tell me what a reliquary is? Oh, yeah, a reliquary, it's just a little, it's just a little. decorative container, to put it pretty banally, for a relic. Something that it can show the relic. It looks nice. So usually they're a little... I have one right there because I have a little relic of St. John of the Cross. Or no, St. John the Evangelist. But it's just like a little gold thing, probably about the size of a tea lamp, a tea candle, which is right there. Exactly. How did you come up with that? I know, right? But this one was beautiful. It was maybe about like... 10 inches high, and it looked like a little baby monstrance, but it was just beautiful metal work. It's awesome. Anyway, so our pastor's really excited. He had this big, on a Saturday, just invited a bunch of people in the parish and had kind of a, I don't know, enshrinement of the true cross relic at our church. And on Sunday, we processed into it with the actual crucifix that we use for Mass. We processed it with the true cross. That was kind of cool. So I was like, anyway, the true cross is cool. I was talking to people after mass about it, and a lot of people didn't know much about the true cross. They were like, what is it? Where is it? If you look at it, if you look at the relic, it's just like, where is it? You just see this little white circle, and you're like, well, is that it? What is it? In the white circle, there's two little slivers of wood, and I had to explain, and they're shaped in a cross, two slivers crossed like a plus sign. And that was the Vatican. There's paperwork and documentation from the Vatican. The Vatican's pretty strict about it. about the authenticity of relics. And so for a relic to get approved as authentic, there's like this whole process, which I don't have time to go into now, but having documentation makes it pretty certain. There's a few things that they know of where like this particular thing was falsified, but they know how to find that. If you have the documentation, you have somebody who knows how to look at it, they can be like, no, this is legit. So anyway, that was kind of cool. So, and on the Feast of the True Cross, our buddy Mason. who lives with us, he's a seminarian in our house, he brought down a relic of the true cross he had that I didn't know. And it was given to him by an old guy who passed away a couple years ago. It was left in his will. He left two things in his will. One thing to somebody else, and then this relic of the true cross to Mason. To Mason. Yeah, isn't that amazing? And it was given to him when he was a child by another couple. So anyway, lots of true cross relics floating around. So I figured it would be a cool thing to talk about the true cross. So what is the true cross? Obviously, if you haven't picked this up already, it's the actual... cross, the piece of wood that our Lord was crucified on at the end of his life, before, at the end of his life, the beginning of our salvation. Right. And we know that Christians adored and venerated this cross in the early church after it happened. I mean, some people might be like, well, why do we even have relics? Why do we, do we like worship this thing? What do we do with it? You know, how do you, we say venerate it. Is that like the same? Do we venerate it like we venerate God? Like, how does that work? but we do know that Christians have been venerating it from the very early church because we have church fathers like Tertullian and a few other guys who actually are defending their apologists. So they're defending the church against people accusing the church of stuff. and one of the accusations that they defend themselves against and the church against is venerating the cross. Like, no, we're not worshiping the cross, but it's because of the cross, what our Savior did on the cross that we venerate the cross, and by venerating the cross, we do give honor to Christ. And that's already there in the early centuries of the church. Now, something happened a couple centuries after Christ that the Roman Emperor Hadrian, came into power, and he was one of the big persecutors of Christianity. And Hadrian's whole thing was like, the empire was falling apart, and the greatest way to unite the Roman Empire was to make sure we're all worshiping the same religion. Because religion was very tied up with the culture, and if we all have the same culture, then we're all kind of on the same board. So when he saw the empire starting to be fragmented, he said, we need to get one religion back here again. And so what that meant was persecuting all the other religions. And so Christianity was, they had, Christians had been venerating. you know, the Holy Sepulcher, the tomb of Christ, Calvary where Christ died, and different holy places in Jerusalem. But Adrian took over, and he wouldn't just, you know, destroy whatever the Christians had done. He would destroy it and then build a pagan temple on top of it. That was kind of their way to kind of supplant other religions propping up, you know. So he built a temple on the site that is now known to be the site of the Holy Sepulcher and Calvary and stuff. And so... the true sites, you know, where the Holy Sepulchre was, where Calvary was, where the true cross was, was kind of lost because Christians had to flee Jerusalem. It was a big mess. And it wasn't until Constantine, which was in 3, was it 312? Yeah. Constantine in the 4th century came into power and became a Christian. and kind of allowed for Christians to go back to the holy places in Jerusalem to venerate them and to find them. So the story goes, and this has been told by a number of early church historians, Eusebius, a bunch of others. I mean, their stories differ to some degree, but there's a lot of common elements that make it sound like, okay, there's something real happened here. So the story is this, that Constantine's mother, who is Saint Helena, Helena, or Helen... she saw it as her mission to go back and recover these holy places and to build churches over them. So she went down, she tried to find Mount Sinai, and she went to Jerusalem to try to find where the true cross was and to find the Holy Sepulcher and a number of different places. So she went to this temple where Hadrian was, and they did a lot of excavations there. And she is the one, while they were doing excavations, they found three crosses. deep and if you get if you go to jerusalem now i was there this summer or not this summer two summers ago and it was super have you been there before so you know what place i'm talking about in the church of holy sepulcher yeah you go down down down yeah you go down down down so there's this church of holy sepulcher is like the coolest thing in the world there's like all these wild passageways and calvary's like up these stairs kind of to the side and the holy sepulcher is only less than like 60 yards away it's really cool um but there's one point where you just go down these steps and you can see there's all these crosses carved into the stonework from the Crusaders. Yeah. So if you've ever been there before, this is the place I'm talking about. You go down these steps where you see all these crosses carved on the wall, and there's this little chapel there, Eastern Orthodox Chapel. And then you keep going down from there, and there is a small little shrine dedicated to the place where St. Helen found the true cross. And it's this beautiful, it's like the very, I don't know how far below the rest of the church it is, but it's just down a bunch of stairs. And I... got a chance to do a holy row down there, which is really cool. It's just really dark and beautiful. There's a little statue of St. Helen withholding the true cross. And how the story goes, she found these three crosses, and they presumed that these are the three crosses of Calvary. There were the two thieves, and Christ was crucified. But they didn't know which cross was which. So what they did was they had a leper come, and he would touch his sores to the cross, to each cross. to find out which one was the true one, because they presumed, hey, if the true cross, we're praying that God would reveal which one's the true cross by healing the leper. And sure enough, one of them he touches, he's healed, this is the true cross. So they took this cross, and there was all these venerations to it all over the church. I mean, it was a renowned thing. It was kind of a prized thing in Constantine's world, a veneration of the true cross, you know. And then... So right now, what happened? We have this cross, we have a huge cross that we're venerating in the early church, but now we don't really have a true cross anymore. Now we have all these little splinters of the true cross all over the world. Mason has one up in our chapel upstairs. We have one in Immaculate Heart of Mary, North Glen. At one point in the church's history, it was really common for every single parish to have a small relic of the true cross. This is centuries ago. Now I don't know if we have enough to cover every single parish. But... So what happened to the cross? Why is it all these little splinters? So what happened is in the 7th century, there were some Persians who attacked Jerusalem, overtook it and stole the true cross, took it as a trophy. They took the cross as a trophy, and the Persians had the cross for, I think, like four centuries until the Crusaders took it back. I think in the 1100s or 10 hundreds. But when they took it back, what they did was they broke the cross and there were already some relics of the true call. Like they had taken off some pieces to make as relics, you know? But what they did, they decided to break the true cross up into relics and to, and to kind of disperse it throughout the world. So that it couldn't be, so that could never be stolen again, never be taken again, that it would be in the possession of not just like one church, but it would be possession of the entire church. you know, manifested by these small local churches who have a small relic. So it's kind of a beautiful symbol of the church's unity to have, like, the parts of the cross be given to the entire church. So they're kind of spread throughout the world. And so that's why we all have these little slivers of the cross. For the last millennium, they've been kind of passing through. Exactly, they've been kind of passing through. So it's interesting. But one of the things that you heard people say, and I think Luther had said this, and it's kind of been one of the... Yeah. rationalistic critiques, I guess, of the whole thing, because he was really critical of the way Catholics used relics, venerated relics, and he just saw a lot of just hypocrisy and kind of like stuff that distracted from the real gospel. And there's probably some truth in that. Sometimes people were so kind of like, and you even see this today with some people. I'll see some guys who are so crazy about relics, you know, but they're not like, you know, they don't even like treat the Eucharist. It's just crazy, you know, how some people can get it bad. We have to have a proper understanding of it. relics and why we have them and we've done podcasts on that before i think we have did we do one on relics i don't know i feel like we've talked about something with relics i have no idea what we've done oh incorruptibles incorrect that was the one we didn't there you go um anyway so he was critical of that and uh and how many relics of the true cross he felt like there were and he one of the lines uh that either he said it was attributed to him or maybe it was somebody else but it was kind of a comment saying that if you put all the parts of the true cross together you would have way, way more than a true cross. In fact, it would be as big as a battleship. That's how many... And basically saying, like, there's so many fake pieces of the true cross, probably that everybody must have part of the true cross. You know, everybody and their grandmother does, you know. Mason Fraley has part of the true cross. That guy. That's crazy. So it's interesting, but there's a little study done by this guy named Rohalt de Fleury. You can find this. There's an article on newadvent.org, I think it is. I think so, yeah. Catholic Encyclopedia, where you can see a thing about the true cross. And he cites this study there. But this... this study he does, I'll just read from the article because I thought it was so great. But he says, this study by Ruholt de Fleury deserves more prolonged attention because he says, its author, so the guy who did the study, has sought out with great care and learning all the relics of the true cross. So he went up and found, you know, where are all the relics and how many, how many do we have? And he, drawn up by a catalog of them, and thanks to his labor, he has succeeded in showing that in spite of what various Protestant or rationalistic authors have pretended. the fragments of the cross brought together again would not only be comparable in bulk to a battleship, but would not reach one-third that of a cross, which is supposed to have been three or four meters in height, with traverse branch of two meters. So he basically says this is how big the cross would have been. So he says if the cross was this size, which is a really common size from what we know of archaeological studies and how the Romans crucified people, it would weigh, it was presumably made of pine wood because that was the most common wood that they would use for these. It would be 75 kilograms. We'd find that the volume of the cross would be about 178 million cubic millimeters. And he kind of put together all the relics of the true cross that we know of in existence. And he said they only amount to 4 million cubic millimeters, which is one-third of what the true cross would have been. So, I mean, he just did a study just to show that, you know, that's kind of a bogus. I mean, it seems like there's a lot, but it's really not that much of what we know of the true cross. So I just thought that was an interesting study to have. But, um... Yeah, good stuff. Yeah, this is all, this is the true cross. It's a cool thing that we have, and it's just beautiful. If you ever have a chance to check out a relic of the true cross, a lot of parishes have it. A lot of times they'll be in the altar or sometimes in the crucifix. So if you have a crucifix in your parish or there's a crucifix mounted on the wall and there'll be a little circle on the bottom of it or something like that, a lot of times that circle is a relic of the true cross. So it's just a beautiful, a beautiful symbol of our unity. And just the... And we always go back and talk about this, but kind of the nitty-gritty and the sensible dimension of our faith, that it's not just this abstract thing where we just have these ideas, and all these things kind of happen in Bible land somewhere, but like, no, no, Jesus, he was a real man, and he really was crucified on the cross. In fact, here's a piece of the cross, and like, the saints say, Peter, he was real. Like we have his bones in St. Peter's Basilica. St. John the Evangelist was a real man. He was a man in Galilee, and I have a piece of his bone in my room right now. It's just crazy. But this isn't just like, this is historical. It also transcends history. But that's why relics are important, because they remind us of that. And we honor God, and we honor what God did by honoring the cross itself. And I think that last thing is just so important, that God works in existence in concrete, historical ways. And he transforms people. and he transforms these things called the saints and so it is kind of creepy uh sometimes the way catholics kind of get into this stuff totally weird but but it is fitting catholic stuff podcast at gmail.com on facebook catholic stuff podcast never on twitter we'll see you next week hopefully it's becoming a mantra hopefully see you

summarization.results: A podcast discussion highlighted the veneration of relics, particularly the True Cross, believed to be the one on which Jesus was crucified. The relic found by St. Helena in Jerusalem was later dispersed worldwide as a symbol of unity in the Church. Despite criticism from figures like Luther, relics like these serve as tangible reminders of faith grounded in history and the transformative power of God, revered in Catholic tradition.
